;;利物浦前锋路易斯·迪亚兹的父亲路易斯·曼努埃尔·迪亚兹在被ELN释放后受到妻子西莱尼斯·马鲁兰达的安慰在经历了 12 天的绑架折磨后。
;

;利物浦足球运动员路易斯·迪亚斯的父亲公开讲述了他在哥伦比亚和委内瑞拉边境被武装游击队俘虏时如何忍受了近两周的艰苦跋涉和不眠之夜。 .

;

;58 岁的路易斯·曼努埃尔·迪亚斯 (Luis Manuel Díaz) 说：“骑马很多次，真的很辛苦，有很多山，很多雨，还有太多昆虫。”身体虚弱的迪亚兹在家人的搀扶下上下椅子，他在家乡哥伦比亚巴兰卡斯对记者说：“我无法安然入睡，这非常困难，几乎12天没有睡觉。”

;

;他说他非常高兴，因为他;被民族解放军 (ELN) 游击队扣为人质后于 11 月 9 日与家人团聚。

;

;迪亚兹最初以为他告诉记者，他被绑架是为了索取赎金，但从未支付任何金钱来换取他的自由。他的妻子 Cilenis Marulanda 也被枪口绑架，但几小时内就被释放。

;
;

;;相关：;;“他看起来真的很高兴”：克洛普讲述迪亚兹在父亲获释后的喜悦;

; < /aside>;

;“我仍然无法理解我被绑架的原因是什么，[游击队]说我和任何人都没有问题。”

;

;警方怀疑当地犯罪分子已经;绑架迪亚兹; 来自北部拉瓜希拉省的巴兰卡斯，但政府和平谈判于 11 月 2 日透露，他落入左翼叛乱分子手中。

;

;ELN 由激进牧师于 1964 年创立，目前估计有2,500 名战士负责该武装组织的勒索和贩毒活动。

;

;哥伦比亚警方周六上午表示，在英国情报部门支持的一次行动后，逮捕了四名嫌疑人。

;

;当地贩毒黑手党洛斯普里莫斯 (Los Primos)，[the Cousins]，涉嫌抓获迪亚兹并将其交给哥伦比亚报纸 ELN; El Tiempo 报道。;

;

;迪亚兹 (Díaz)，他经营一家当地儿童足球基金会表示，第三天他被交给游击队后，他受到了更好的待遇，绑架者承诺尽快释放他。

;

;“他们告诉我要冷静“我不会发生任何事情，因为我知道我在镇上是一个谦虚且受人爱戴的人，因为我所做的工作，”他说。

;

;迪亚兹的被捕使民族解放军成为国际关注的焦点，威胁要破坏武装组织与哥伦比亚政府之间的和平谈判。

;

;上周日，路易斯·迪亚斯在对阵卢顿镇的最后时刻扳平比分后，举起了利物浦球衣，透露了一条信息，呼吁释放他的父亲。< /p>;

;他的父亲表示，周四他能够与儿子交谈，因为就在利物浦球员对阵图卢兹的比赛之前，他被释放了。 “在他为俱乐部踢比赛之前，我有机会向他打招呼。 [他]很满足，很高兴，因为我已经和家人在一起了。”

;

;ELN 最高指挥官本周告诉当地媒体，绑架这位英超球星的父亲是一起;“错误”; 但它不会停止绑架勒索。

;

;该组织;6 月份与政府同意为期六个月的停火;，并规定将停止这种做法。

;

;迪亚兹表示他不会离开巴兰卡斯尽管经历了痛苦的经历，但仍鼓励该国继续努力寻找和平方式摆脱六十多年的内部冲突。 “让我们放下武器，使用笔和笔记本，”他说。

; Sun, 12 Nov 2023 09:22:01 +0800 Lost in space: astronaut’s toolbag orbits Earth after escaping during spacewalkhttps://www.theguardian.com/science/2023/nov/11/astronaut-toolbag-earth-spacewalk
;;2023-11-12T00:37:58Z;
;
;;一张在太空中拍摄的照片，远处是深黑色，右上角是地球大气层的蓝色光芒，照片中两名宇航员面向金属空间站外面的大型白色服装。
;

;天空观察者有一个新的太空物体可以训练他们的视线：一个现在漂浮在地球周围太空中的工具包。

;

;美国宇航局宇航员贾斯明根据 ;美国宇航局;。

;

;宇航员们在第一次太空行走时正在修理组件，以允许据 SciTechDaily 报道，国际空间站太阳能电池阵列可连续跟踪太阳，该报;记录了太空行走;.

;
;

;;相关：;;欧几里得望远镜发回‘黑暗宇宙’任务的第一批图像;

;
;

;“活动期间，无意中丢失了一个工具包。飞行控制人员使用外部站摄像机发现了工具包。太空行走的剩余时间不需要这些工具。任务控制中心分析了该袋子的轨迹，并确定重新联系空间站的风险很低，并且机上人员和空间站都很安全，无需采取任何行动。”美国宇航局在其博客上表示。

;

;这个白色的挎包-就像袋子出奇地明亮，闪烁的光正好低于肉眼的能见度极限，这意味着观察者可以使用双筒望远镜发现它，;根据 EarthSky;。它的视星等约为 6，使其亮度略低于冰巨星天王星。

;

;要跟踪这个袋子，观测者只需找到国际空间站，它是夜空中第三亮的天体据美国宇航局称，可以使用该机构的;定位空间站;工具进行定位。该袋子将比国际空间站提前两到四分钟绕地球运行。

;

;日本宇航员古川聪上周发现该袋子漂浮在富士山上空。

; ;

;宇航员梅甘娜·克里斯蒂安确认其正在被跟踪。

; ;

;丢失的太空装备应该在;迅速下降;并在地球大气层的炽热地狱中遭遇厄运。据EarthSky报道，初步估计该工具包应该会在2024年3月左右重新进入大气层。

;

;这并不是第一次有物体在太空中丢失，甚至也不是第一个工具包丢失。 2008 年，海德玛丽·斯特凡尼辛-派珀 (Heidemarie Stefanyshyn-Piper) 在尝试修复损坏的行李时，发现她的;包滑落;。一部分在国际空间站上。那个包的丢失导致任务控制人员改变了奋进号航天飞机任务期间计划的剩余太空行走计划。

;

;2006 年，已故宇航员皮尔斯·塞勒斯 ;在测试隔热罩修复技术时在太空深处丢失了铲子;。卖家当时正在使用该工具将粘稠的隔热罩粘液涂抹到故意损坏的样品上，当时他对这次损失感到遗憾：“那是我最喜欢的抹布……不要告诉其他抹刀。”

; Sun, 12 Nov 2023 09:22:01 +0800 Sunak will be weakened if he fails to sack Braverman, warn senior Torieshttps://www.theguardian.com/politics/2023/nov/11/sunak-sack-braverman-warn-senior-tories
;;2023-11-11T19:00:03Z;
;
;;Rishi Sunak 和 Suella Braverman 坐在内阁会议桌旁
;

;Rishi Sunak 作为总理的权威将是高级保守党人士表示，除非他在几天之内解雇备受争议和分裂的内政大臣苏埃拉·布雷弗曼(Suella Braverman)，否则他将陷入崩溃。最保守派人士认为，苏纳克将在本周初解雇布雷弗曼，为内阁改组开辟道路，他的盟友希望这可能会重振他的首相职位。

;

;虽然内政大臣在少数右翼人士中得到了一些支持温和派后座议员要求唐宁街在停战日纪念活动和今天在伦敦举行的亲巴勒斯坦游行后尽快解雇布雷弗曼，议员们和党鞭对此感到不知所措。

;

;一位前内阁大臣告诉 ;观察家;指出，尽管布雷弗曼上周为《泰晤士报》撰写文章时显然是“试图被解雇”，她在文中指责警方表现出有利于支持者的偏见巴勒斯坦“暴徒”，苏纳克别无选择，只能解雇她。

;

;“不解雇她将是致命的，因为到那时，他不仅是一个不受欢迎的总理，而且变得软弱和不受欢迎。 ”

;

;布雷弗曼还对该党的选举吸引力造成了难以估量的损害，他说：“很多同事都说，苏埃拉的潜在信息只会赶走英格兰东南部的选民。不能允许这种情况继续下去。”

;

;在谈到布雷弗曼最近提出的无家可归者之所以走上街头是因为他们做出了“生活方式的选择”时，这位资深保守党人补充道：“那是跨越卢比孔河。当你开始攻击无家可归者并说这是一种生活方式的选择时，这显然是无知的，而且是令人讨厌的。”当被问及他对布雷弗曼的行为有多愤怒（从 1 到 10）时，他回答“11”。

;

;对内政大臣蔑视的愤怒 - 她被要求降低她的;时报;

;布雷弗曼关于警察偏见的言论不仅被认为具有分裂性，而且是危险的，在大选前煽动分裂。今天的亲巴勒斯坦游行和停战日活动。昨天，她会见了大都会专员马克·罗利，显然是为了缓解紧张局势。

;

;就连党内大人物也公开表示，现在是布雷弗曼被赶出内阁的时候了， 1922 年后座议员委员会前副主席查尔斯·沃克爵士 (Sir Charles Walker) 表示：“如果没有她，内阁会是一个更快乐的地方，而且议会党会是一个更好的地方，每个人都不必担心她接下来要说什么。”

;

;他补充道：“内政大臣的好战行为表明，她可能更愿意领导改革党，而不是被领导。”保守党成员。她可能认为她已经找到了答案，但如果复杂问题有简单的解决方案，我们现在就已经找到了。政治很难驾驭。那些做得最好的人会带着细微差别、同情心和理解来行事。”

;

;马丁·维克斯 (Martin Vickers) 是 1922 年委员会执行委员，很少公开批评部长们，她说她做得太过分了，结果是媒体对上周国王演讲的报道被她引起的争议所淹没。他说：“我们不能出现内政大臣与专员公开争吵的情况。”另一位“红墙”席位上有影响力的后座议员表示，布雷弗曼有权表达她的观点。这是一个珍视言论自由权的国家，但又补充说，“然而，她应该在她所属的后座议员中这样做”。

;

;布雷弗曼的保守党批评者表示，任何解雇她的决定的时机都是正确的批评者认为苏纳克必须在 ;最高法院周三;裁定她将寻求庇护者送往卢旺达的政策的合法性。

;

;“他不能等到判决之后，因为如果政府获胜，这将是苏埃拉的胜利，她的实力也会得到加强。另一方面，如果她输了，首相将被视为因有关他支持的政策的法庭案件结果而解雇她。所以必须在本周早些时候完成。一位人士表示：“我的钱是星期一。”一位人士表示。

;

;虽然有传言称，如果她被解雇，一些支持布雷弗曼的部长就会辞职，但他们相信，如果她在大选后领导该党，他们将处于领先地位下一次大选 - 大多数议员表示，她在党内缺乏广泛的支持，无论是在议会还是在国家。

;

;同样令温和派议员愤怒的是，正如有人所说，“少数头脑风暴者”正在破坏该党的选举希望。 “这完全令人沮丧且功能失调。我们被一小部分人扣为人质，他们似乎认为我们通过挑衅各种群体和不同意“当权派”来提高受欢迎程度。显而易见的事实是它正在摧毁我们。首相需要决定让内政大臣继续任职，让她那帮快乐的人微笑，是否真的值得。”

;

;另一位温和派议员表示，解雇布雷弗曼会引发辞职是不正确的。她的盟友。他说：“显而易见的是，大多数议会党员对内政大臣深感不安，不仅因为观点本身，还因为她很糟糕且无能。” “更大的问题是，她的意义何在？我们没有得到政治利益。我们没有能力。很混乱。这里没有策略。”

;

;前司法部长大卫·高克也批评了布雷弗曼的干预。他说：“苏埃拉·布雷弗曼有自己的议程，这与履行内政大臣的职责或帮助她的政党向国家展示一个有凝聚力和统一的政府无关。” “她完全有权对亲巴勒斯坦抗议活动的各个方面表示担忧，但她干预的性质只会让警察的任务变得更加困难。”

;

;与此同时，工党高级官员指责布雷弗曼煽动煽动。就在停战日两分钟默哀前不久，活动人士汤米·罗宾逊和足球流氓的支持者冲破了警察防线，导致极右翼针对警察的暴力行为。

;

;伦敦市长萨迪克·汗 (Sadiq Khan) 表示： “我们在纪念碑上看到的极右翼混乱场面是内政大臣言论的直接结果。警察的工作变得更加困难。”苏格兰首席大臣胡姆扎·优素福 (Humza Yousaf) 表示，极右翼势力受到布雷弗曼的鼓舞，并得出结论，“她必须辞职”。

;
;
;

;任何解雇布雷弗曼的决定的时机都至关重要对于苏纳克来说，一些人认为他必须在最高法院周三就她的卢旺达政策做出裁决之前除掉她

;
;
;

; Sun, 12 Nov 2023 03:52:01 +0800 Donald Trump pushes for live broadcast of his trial over election subversionhttps://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2023/nov/11/donald-trump-live-broadcast-election-subversion-trial
;;2023-11-11T16:58:11Z;
;
;;特朗普傻笑。
;

;;唐纳德·特朗普;的律师已请求授权在法庭上对他的审判进行现场电视报道，指控他密谋推翻 2020 年总统选举周五晚些时候提交的法律文件援引了未经证实的指控，即特朗普是拜登白宫迫害的受害者，支持了这一说法。新闻机构努力提供审判内部的电视直播报道，审判定于 2024 年 3 月开始。

;

;一项已实施数十年的规则禁止电视转播联邦法院的刑事和民事诉讼程序，一般可以由公众亲自参加。特朗普律师提交的五页提交材料并未提及该规则。

;

;“检方希望在黑暗中继续这种嘲讽。特朗普总统呼吁阳光，”《Politico》首先报道的;文件;断言。 “美国内外的每个人都应该有机会直接研究此案，并观察特朗普总统在审判后是否会为自己免除这些毫无根据且出于政治动机的指控。”

;

;该文件最后重申了特朗普的说法，即他认为选举是“被操纵和窃取的”。

;

;本案检察官;援引;联邦法院反对广播的裁决来回应众多媒体的努力请求允许在电视上直播审判。政府还辩称，电视转播审判可能会给诉讼程序带来风险，包括促进对证人和陪审员的潜在恐吓。

;

;新闻媒体在其论点中引用了公众对此案的不同寻常的兴趣程度以及在法院容纳审判旁听者方面可预见的问题。

;

;特朗普正在努力应对四项刑事起诉和几项民事诉讼，试图在 2024 年共和党竞选之前将法律风险重新塑造为向选民提供的平台共和党的白宫提名。

;

;特朗普被广泛认为是明年共和党总统候选人的热门人选，但他已被禁止使用社交媒体平台谴责检察官、潜在的潜在威胁。证人和法庭工作人员。这位前总统抱怨禁言令侵犯了他的总统竞选活动以及美国宪法第一修正案规定的言论自由权。

;

;电视直播报道可以作为规避禁言令的一种手段。< /p>;

;在禁言令实施之前，特朗普曾称该案的特别检察官杰克·史密斯“精神错乱”。这位前总统还对其前白宫办公厅主任马克·梅多斯向大陪审团提供的证词发表了评论。

;

;该案的检察官表示，特朗普显然一直在寻求“向本案中可预见的证人”。

;

;10 月下旬，美国地区法官 Tanya Chutkan ;在之前选择暂时搁置该措施后，裁定;支持实施禁言令。法官还驳回了特朗普暂停该命令的请求，而他的律师则向上级法院提出上诉。

; Sun, 12 Nov 2023 01:22:02 +0800 Oysters and ice-cream: menu for dinner on Titanic expected to sell for £70,000https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2023/nov/11/menu-dinner-titanic-expected-sell-70000-auction

;
;;带有印刷内容的水渍卡片的特写，包括阿斯伯格奶油、三文鱼荷兰酱等物品，银鱼，牛肉 Tournedos
;

;对于泰坦尼克号上的头等舱乘客来说，这并不是最后的晚餐，但也很接近了。一份 1912 年 4 月 11 日幸存的独特游轮菜单于本周末被拍卖，揭示了这艘注定失败的客轮在其首次横渡大西洋的处女航中撞上冰山前三天提供的美食。

;

;预计售价高达 70,000 英镑，菜单提出了一些有趣的问题：其中，谁在前往救生艇时抓起了菜单，维多利亚布丁是什么？

;

;

;在拍卖会上，泰坦尼克号纪念品分为广泛的类别，每个类别都有不同的地位。有些是从沉船中打捞出来的，有些是幸存者拥有的，还有一些，比如 4 月 11 日的丰盛晚餐菜单，很可能已从船上移走作为纪念品。

; Sun, 12 Nov 2023 00:22:02 +0800 ‘Unthinkable cruelty’: Kenyan expert working at Bristol University denied visa for six-year-old daughterhttps://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2023/nov/11/kenyan-expert-bristol-university-denied-visa-daughter
;;2023-11-11T15:00:38Z;
;
;;Doseline Kiguru 博士
;

;肯尼亚世界文学专家 Doseline Kiguru 博士欣喜若狂。她在布里斯托尔大学获得了永久职位。但这一切都在上周发生了变化，内政部拒绝让她六岁的女儿与她团聚。

;

;这一决定被愤怒的同事称为“难以想象的残忍行为”，将加剧人们的恐惧政府不成比例地阻止来自南半球的学者来到英国，尽管 Rishi Sunak 的 ;承诺让英国成为全球“科学超级大国;”。

;

;它呼应了;两个类似的2019 年的案例;，在受到世界各地学术界的广泛谴责后，内政部被迫态度大转变，拒绝牛津大学两名女研究人员的孩子入境。

;

;学者们表示，禁止研究人员的孩子的情况并不少见，但家长通常不敢公开。基古鲁本周末表示，她对禁止女儿移居英国的“可怕”决定感到“震惊”，并且无法忍受“想到她在肯尼亚感到多么孤独和孤立”。

; <基古鲁说，她的女儿每天都会打电话问她什么时候来接她。 “当然，孩子不理解这些[签证]的复杂性。她认为我离开了她。”

;

;她于 2021 年首次来到布里斯托尔，担任欧盟资助的 130 万英镑非洲文学行动主义项目的研究员。她的实地工作需要她在肯尼亚度过大量时间，因此家人决定没有必要让她的女儿背井离乡。

;

;然而，当她获得永久讲师职位时，她决心创办一个与女儿在英国开始新生活。她的丈夫也是一名学者，无法照顾女儿，因为他经常出差进行研究，但希望搬到英国。

;

;Kiguru 于 7 月返回肯尼亚为女儿申请签证。预计不会出现任何问题，她从 9 月份开始就为她在布里斯托尔的一所小学注册，并购买了校服。

;

;签证流程本应需要 15 个工作日，但直到 11 月初布里斯托尔大学介入才得以完成。她发现女儿的申请在十月初被拒绝了。她现在只剩下一周的时间提出上诉。

;

;内政部拒绝了这一决定，称其认为“没有同情心的理由”允许孩子与母亲团聚。这封写给六岁女孩的信补充道：“前往英国是你母亲的个人决定。”内政部用她自己的签证进行报复，说：“这意味着多塞琳选择离开她的女儿。这种推理的敌意只能来自种族主义和厌女症，让我屏住呼吸。”布里斯托尔大学非洲、世界和比较文学教授马杜·克里希南 (Madhu Krishnan) 说：“以如此虚假的理由将年幼的孩子与母亲分开的决定是一种难以想象的残忍行为，令人遗憾的是，近年来我们已经熟悉了这种行为。”

;

;她将基古鲁描述为“世界领先的学者” ”并表示，如果这迫使她离开英国，她将“强烈感受到”她的损失。

;

;A ;英国皇家学会最近的报告;发现学术签证经常因“任意和主观”原因被拒绝。报告称，申请访问签证（科学家需要访问英国的研究会议）的非洲国民被拒绝的可能性是东亚申请人的三到四倍。

;

;该报告描述了一次研究会议that was focused on gathering insights from the global south, but ended up with no attenders from that part of the world.

;

;The society has denounced “disproportionate” increases to visa fees, planned from next year, as a “punitive tax on talent”, with top researchers coming to the UK facing costs up to 10 times higher than other leading science nations.

;

;Sir Adrian Smith, the society's president, said: “If the UK is to truly be a world leader in the competitive global research environment, we need urgent action to remove these barriers.”

;

;A Home Office spokesperson said they did not comment on individual cases but added: “All visa applications are considered on their individual merits in accordance with the immigration rules.”

; Sat, 11 Nov 2023 23:22:01 +0800 Gay Games delight Hong Kong amid China’s growing hostility to LGBTQ+ communityhttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/nov/11/gay-games-hong-kong-china-hostility-gay-transgender
;;2023-11-11T15:00:38Z;
;
;;Lion dance performers take to the stage during the opening ceremony of the Gay Games on 4 November 2023
;

;After months of pandemic-related delays, Asia's first Gay Games was ;held in Hong Kong last week;, with nearly 2,400 athletes competing. At the opening ceremony, Regina Ip, the convenor of Hong Kong's executive council, said the competition represented the city's commitment to “equal opportunity and non-discrimination”, and praised Hong Kong's courts for the “numerous judgments” handed down in favour of the LGBTQ+ community in the past decade.

;

;This was met with bemusement by activists and lawyers, who pointed out that Ip's government has opposed each of those judgments, losing in nearly every single case. Since 2018, there have been at least seven cases relating to LGBTQ+ rights heard by Hong Kong's courts, with many reaching the Court of Final Appeal, the city's highest bench. “Why are they still wasting taxpayers' money fighting these tooth-and-nail litigations when they're recycling the same arguments and losing?” said Mark Daly, a human rights lawyer who has worked on a number of the cases.

;

;Ip told the ;Observer; that “the government had complied with the Court of Final Appeal's rulings” in all of the cases that made it to the top court.

;

;The Gay Games were hosted in the wake of a string of legal victories for the LGBTQ+ community, whose success in the courts stands in stark contrast to the increasingly hostile environment for gay and transgender people in mainland China.

;

;In February, Hong Kong's top court ruled that the policy of requiring trans people to undergo sex reassignment surgery to change their legal gender – which is also required by law in mainland China – was unconstitutional. Then in September, ;the court ruled; that the government was obliged to establish an “alternative framework” for the legal recognition of same-sex unions, while stopping short of endorsing gay marriage.

;

;Several recent cases have involved Henry Li, a 37-year-old solicitor who became a reluctant activist in 2019 after he and his late husband, Edgar Ng, realised that they would not be able to legally live together in the government-subsidised flat bought by Ng because Li could not register as a “spouse” or a “family member”. Ng and Li had married in the UK in 2017 but their union was not legally recognised in Hong Kong.

;

;The legal action was “not really to fight for equality, it was a fight to stay together lawfully in our own home,” said Li, who credits Ng with initiating the judicial review to “protect” him. Last month, the Court of Appeal ;ruled in Li's favour;, although the housing authority is appealing.

;

;Ng also launched a legal bid to demand equal treatment for same-sex couples with regards to inheritance rights. Last month, the Court of Appeal upheld a lower bench's ruling in Ng's favour. But Ng died in 2020, having taken his own life, and his assets remain frozen as the government is expected to appeal.

; ;

;Ng's death led to yet more litigation after the morgue refused to let Li identify Ng's body. “It was cruel, inhumane and demeaning. Edgar's body was literally in the next room when I was told he's not my husband,” Li recalled.

;

;He filed a judicial review but dropped it in October 2021 after the government clarified that same-sex partners should be treated equally by the coroner's office.

;

;The government's resistance to granting LGBTQ+ people equal rights is in line with Beijing but increasingly at odds with public opinion in Hong Kong. A ;survey; published in May found that 60% of people supported the idea of same-sex marriage, up from 38% a decade ago. More than 70% said that Hong Kong should have a law to protect against discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation.

;

;It is not just in the courts that LGBTQ+ people have clashed with the authorities.; ;In July, Hong Kong's public broadcaster suspended the city's only LGBTQ+-related radio show, ;We Are Family;, which had run for 17 years. No official reason was given for the show's cancellation, but since the passing of a controversial national security law in 2020, imposed by Beijing to quell the months of pro-democracy protests, anything that could be perceived as being critical of the Chinese authorities has become sensitive. The annual Pride march was cancelled in 2020 because of Covid-19 restrictions but shows no signs of returning – although a pop-up Pride exhibition is planned.

;

;Evelyn Tsao, a human rights lawyer who focuses on LGBTQ+ issues, says that “more and more” nonprofit organisations are “restricting the scope of their advocacy work to do only public education … and we see less and less of the LGBT rights groups speaking out against public policy or doing any lobbying work in the political sense.”

;

;Daly noted that while the political atmosphere has not directly affected civil rights litigation, there is “probably a little bit more of a chill” for anyone challenging the government in the courts.

;

;There are some in the pro-democracy camp who balk at the idea that gay rights can be separated from the wider crackdown on freedoms in Hong Kong. In June, a group of activists ;called; for the Gay Games to be cancelled and accused the organisers of aligning themselves with “figures responsible for widespread persecution against the people of Hong Kong”. On the other end of the political spectrum, Junius Ho, a firebrand pro-Beijing legislator, has explicitly said that the games could contravene the national security law.

;

;David Ko, the communications director for the games, said that the event was not aligned “with any political ideologies or figures … Our primary goal is to create a platform where individuals from all walks of life can come together to celebrate diversity, inclusivity and the human spirit.”

;

;But the games have struggled to stay out of politics. Taiwan, the only place in Asia to have legalised gay marriage, did not send a delegation to the event in Hong Kong, citing concerns about athletes' safety in the context of the national security law.

;

;Four Ohio Republican state lawmakers are seeking to strip judges of their power to interpret an abortion rights amendment after ;voters opted to enshrine those rights in the state's constitution this week;.

;
;

;;Related: ;;'Ohio spoke tonight': voters add abortion rights to state constitution;

;
;

;Republican state house representatives Jennifer Gross, Bill Dean, Melanie Miller and Beth Lear said in ;a news release; on Thursday that they will push to have Ohio's legislature – not the courts – make any decisions about the amendment passed on Tuesday.

;

;“To prevent mischief by pro-abortion courts with [the amendment], Ohio legislators will consider removing jurisdiction from the judiciary over this ambiguous ballot initiative,” said the mix of fairly new and veteran lawmakers who are all vice-chairs of various house committees. “The Ohio legislature alone will consider what, if any, modifications to make to existing laws based on public hearings and input from legal experts on both sides.”

;

;The statement also contained unsubstantiated references to “foreign election interference” by billionaires.

;

;It's the latest development in the struggle over abortion rights between Ohio's Republican-dominated legislature and the majority of the voters, who passed the amendment by a margin of 57% to 43%.

;

;Abortion rights advocates plan to ask the courts to repeal any remaining abortion bans and restrictions on the books in Ohio, including a mandatory 24-hour period that abortion seekers must wait before they can have the procedure and a ban on abortions after a fetal diagnosis of Down's syndrome.

;

;The house speaker, Jason Stephens, declined to comment on the release, according to his spokesperson, Aaron Mulvey. However, Stephens was among the dozens of legislative Republicans who have vowed to fight back against the new amendment.

;

;“The legislature has multiple paths that we will explore to continue to protect innocent life. This is not the end of the conversation,” Stephens previously said in a news release.

;

;If the amendment or any other abortion restrictions were to end up being challenged in the courts, it's unclear how they would fare. The state supreme court has a conservative majority and has the final say over state constitutional issues.

; Sat, 11 Nov 2023 22:52:01 +0800 Lost Doctor Who episodes found – but owner is reluctant to hand them to BBChttps://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2023/nov/11/lost-doctor-who-episodes-found-owner-reluctant-to-hand-them-to-bbc
;;2023-11-11T13:02:36Z;
;
;;Actor William Hartnell in The Daleks in Colour
;

;For ;Doctor Who;-lovers they are the missing crown jewels: lost episodes of the first series of the TV sci-fi drama, shown in the 1960s. But now film recordings of not just one, but two of the early BBC adventures, both featuring the first doctor, ;William Hartnell;, has been found in Britain by amateur sleuths.

;

;The episodes, one featuring the Daleks, would offer viewers a chance to travel back in time without the use of a Tardis. But the ;Observer ;has learned that the owners of the rare, rediscovered footage are not prepared to hand it over to the BBC, even as the clock ticks down to the 60th anniversary of the show's launch this month.

;

;Veteran film collector John Franklin believes the answer is for the BBC to announce an immediate general amnesty on missing film footage.

;

;This would reassure British amateur collectors that their private archives will not be confiscated if they come forward and that they will be safe from prosecution for having stored stolen BBC property, something several fear.

;

;“Some of these collectors are petrified,” said Franklin, who knows the location of the two missing ;Doctor Who; episodes, along with several other newly discovered TV treasures, including an episode of the ;The Basil Brush Show;, the second to be unearthed this autumn. “We now need to catalogue and save the significant television shows that are out there. If we are not careful they will eventually be dumped again in house clearances, because a lot of the owners of these important collections are now in their 80s and are very wary,” he added.

;

;Discarded TV film was secretly salvaged from bins and skips by staff and contractors who worked at the BBC between 1967 and 1978, when the corporation had a policy of throwing out old reels. And Hartnell's ;Doctor Who; episodes were far from the only ones to go. Many popular shows were lost and other ;Doctor Who ;adventures starring Patrick Troughton and Jon Pertwee were either jettisoned or erased. A missing early episode of the long-running sitcom ;Sykes;, starring ;Eric Sykes; and Hattie Jacques, has also been rediscovered in private hands in the last few weeks.

; ;

;Franklin, who staged an event entitled Film is Fabulous! for collectors in Leicester last month with the Cinema and Television History Research Institute at De Montfort University, argues that the BBC is best placed to help. “The collectors involved are ex-employees and so are terrified. The rule was that you didn't take anything, even if it had been thrown out. But if you loved film and knew it would be important one day, what did you do? So what we need now is an amnesty,” he said.

;

;Franklin's plea was supported by Mark Stuckey, a film and projector restorer who appears as an electronics expert on the BBC's ;The Repair Shop;. “These collectors were seen as criminals, but now we can see they are really saviours. An amnesty would stop them being frightened of prosecution,” he said.

;

;Last month the BBC admitted its 800-episode back catalogue of ;Doctor Who; shows, ;now available on its iPlayer streaming service;, would be incomplete. Seven episodes from 1963 have been colourised and woven together into a 75-minute long ;monster show;, ;The Daleks in Colour;, which will be shown on BBC Four on 23 November. These will also be made available on the iPlayer.

;

;The BBC said it was ready to talk to anyone with lost episodes. “We welcome members of the public contacting us regarding programmes they believe are lost archive recordings, and are happy to work with them to restore lost or missing programmes to the BBC archives,” it said.

;

;Whether this will be enough to prompt nervous collectors to come forward is doubtful. While collectors are in no real danger, the infamous arrest of comedian Bob Monkhouse in 1978 has not been forgotten, Franklin suspects: “Monkhouse was a private collector and was accused of pirating videos. He even had some of his archive seized. Sadly people still believe they could have their films confiscated.”

;

;Most of the collectors are not interested in selling, but feel they should not be penalised for storing film for 50 years. “If we list all the found footage we could simply go to an auction house and sell it, which would save some of it, but then it could go anywhere. That seems sad, when there is such a growing interest in celluloid among younger people again. It has become quite fashionable,” said Franklin.

;
;

;;Related: ;;Miriam Margolyes to star as 'the Meep' in Doctor Who 60th-anniversary series;

;
;

;“BBC Studios, the corporation's separate, commercial arm, have already spent money animating some lost Hartnell episodes, so surely they could spend a little more on restoring the originals and perhaps pay something to these elderly collectors, a few of whom are now unwell, or caring for others.”

;

;Until the recent discoveries, it was believed that a total of 97 ;Doctor Who ;episodes were missing from the show's first six years. Chris Perry, head of the TV archive Kaleidoscope, has recently claimed that he knows of many in private archives that could be returned, with the right assurances.

;

;After all, as Phil Collinson, executive producer of the new colourised episode has attested, the Hartnell adventures are “a masterpiece of 1960s drama” and “literally the foundation stone of all that Doctor Who has become.”

;

;The modern reboot of the show is to return to television screens on 25 November with the first of three special episodes. They feature ;David Tennant in a return to the role; of the Doctor, before his regeneration into ;Ncuti Gatwa;, the character's 15th incarnation.

; Sat, 11 Nov 2023 21:22:01 +0800 Ex-Nato chief proposes Ukraine joins without Russian-occupied territorieshttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/nov/11/ex-nato-chief-proposes-ukraine-joins-without-russian-occupied-territories
;;2023-11-11T10:18:29Z;
;
;;Nato secretary general, Jens Stoltenberg, during a visit to Ukraine's president, Volodymyr Zelenskiy, in Kyiv, April 2023.
;

;A former Nato secretary general has put forward a proposal for Ukraine to join the military alliance but stripped of the territories occupied by Russia.

;

;Anders Fogh Rasmussen has long worked alongside Andriy Yermak, an adviser to the Ukrainian president, Volodymyr Zelenskiy, particularly ahead of the last Nato summit in Vilnius this year that ended with no invitation for Ukraine to join.

;

;The two men are again broadly discussing Ukraine's place in a new European security architecture, including practical questions around the extent of Ukraine's Nato membership.

;

;Rasmussen, who was Nato's secretary general between 2009 and 2014, insisted that a plan for partial Ukraine membership would not symbolise a freezing of the conflict, but would instead mark a determination to warn Russia that it cannot prevent Ukraine joining the western defensive alliance.

;

;Nato is due to hold its 75th anniversary summit in Washington next summer, and the issue of Ukraine's future membership is bound to be a major topic.

;

;Ukraine's leadership was left bitterly disappointed when, under US and German pressure, Nato at its summit this year issued a statement saying Ukraine would be offered an invitation when conditions allowed, effectively rejecting Ukraine's request to be given a specific date.

;

;Instead, Ukraine's relationship with Nato was elevated on the margins by setting up a Ukraine-Nato council and through an agreement that Nato members bilaterally would offer security guarantees to Ukraine.

;

;Rasmussen said the cause of Ukraine's Nato membership cannot be deferred again next year. He said: “The time has come to take the next step and extend an invitation for Ukraine to join Nato. We need a new European security architecture in which Ukraine is in the heart of Nato.”

;

;Those advocating for Ukraine's Nato membership have been hamstrung by the near-impossibility of a country at war being offered membership, since under Nato's article 5 clause of collective self-defence, all Nato member states are required to come to the active defence of the country in conflict. Nato membership for all of Ukraine now would in effect be a notice to Russia by Nato that it was about to go to war with Moscow.

;

;By excluding from Nato territory held by Russia, the threat of a Russia-Nato conflict would be reduced, Rasmussen argues.

;

;Rasmussen denied the move would freeze the conflict, ceding Ukrainian territory to Russia. He said: “The absolute credibility of article 5 guarantees would deter Russia from mounting attacks inside the Ukrainian territory inside Nato and so free up Ukrainian forces to go to the frontline.”

;

;He said: “To make article 5 credible there would have to be a clear message to Russia that any violation of Nato territory would be met by a response.” He said in some ways the proposal is similar to imposing a no-fly zone on Russia so that it could not fly over Ukrainian territory or send missiles into Ukrainian towns.

;

;Discussions are under way to enlist military specialists ahead of the next Nato summit to work through the details of their idea, including how in the context of shifting frontlines a credible demarcation line could be drawn, showing Ukrainian territory deemed inside Nato and territory occupied by Russia.

;

;Rasmussen said an imprecise precedent existed since west Germany joined the alliance in 1955, and article 5 covered its territory but not that of east Germany.

;

;He set out three principal reasons for Ukraine to be offered membership. Ukraine inside Nato would act as a bulwark against a still-aggressive Russia. Second, he said: “We have to realise that grey zones are danger zones. Neutrality in the old sense of the world does not exist any more. Grey zones become a temptation for Putin to attack.” Finally, he argued the Ukrainian army is now the most battle hardened army in Europe and would be an asset and example to other European powers.

;

;He said a total of 25 countries in addition to the countries inside the G7 were negotiating bilateral security agreements with Ukraine as part of an umbrella agreement called the Kyiv security compact that is supposed to act as a bridge to full Nato membership. The compact includes large-scale weapons transfers, enhanced intelligence sharing and support to Ukraine's defence industry so that it can more independently produce weapons and ammunition.
